pullRequest.body:
Introducing the "linter form" of `#min_imports in`.  The linter is called `linter.minImports` and flags every command that increases the imports-so-far in the file.  When it reaches the end of the file, it also reports which current imports are unneeded and which imports are missing to minimize the current imports.

Here is an example.

```lean
import Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.MinImports
-- `import Mathlib.Data.Int.Notation` flagged as missing
import Mathlib.Data.Nat.Notation   -- flagged as unneeded
import Mathlib.Data.Int.Defs       -- flagged as unneeded

-- Imports increased to [Lean.Parser.Command]
set_option linter.minImports true

-- Imports increased to [Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.MinImports]
#reset_min_imports

-- Imports increased to [Mathlib.Data.Int.Notation, Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.MinImports]
#guard (0 : â„¤) = 0
```

Test PR at #14839.

---

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

`+ previousInstName`

I love the test file!

I'm happy (excited!) to try this out in production.

bors d+

:v: adomani can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10052760293/job/27784462812)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10052760293/job/27784462543)
Could this commented out code be either removed or explained in comments before merging?

I am planning to improve this message: besides warning on each import-bumping declaration, I am also going to make the command tag redundant/missing imports when it parses `eoi`.  This commented out code was simply a debugging message that I have not yet rewritten.
I just pushed a version where the command emits a report upon reaching `eoi` or `#exit`.

Is this functionality not already provided in the `import-graph` repo?

If so, please use, if not, ideally eventually this material could move there, but no hurry.

The closest that I could find in `ImportGraph` is `Lean.Environment.findRedundantImports`, which is the function that I am using in `env.findRedundantImports`.  This is indeed really close: it determines precisely the imports that I want to exclude!  I could not find the command that I defined, since `ImportGraph` proceeds to define some `down`/`upstream` of, containing all imports above or below and, for `#min_imports`, the commands are already mixed up with the `Expr` information with all the declarations in the environment.

I am happy to move this and most of the new `#min_imports` functionality to `ImportGraph`, but I would rather do that later, after testing it in mathlib: I imagine that quite a few improvements will be necessary and doing it within mathlib should have a quicker turnaround and involve fewer inter-repo messing around.
This sentence has a grammar mistake around "that it better suited", but I'm not sure in which way to fix it.
Corrected the mistake and explained a little better.

Will `set_option linter.minImports true` always cause the next command to get a warning?
Should there be a command that sets `minImportsRef` to whatever is currently needed, without getting a warning from *this* linter. (It will be caught during PR review by the linter that flags commands.)

This is a little tricky: the linter knows what are the imports-so-far, only if it has been diligently increasing its "import counter" with every command that it saw.  A switch like the one that you are suggesting would mean that the linter should have updated its counter also when the linter was "off".

I think that this feature is not for this linter in its current form.  If you want to know about whether a specific command increases imports, then you activate the linter at the start of the file and see if this command gets flagged.  If you want to know the imports of just the current command, then you can use `#min_imports in`.  Does that make sense?

What I have not yet decided, is whether the linter should consider `set_option`s as something that increase imports.  In some sense, it currently does and does not: it notices that a `set_option` is a command and adds `Lean.Parser.Command` to the imports, but it does not scan the state for what option it is, so it does not find the file where the option is defined.

Re-reading your comment, it could also be interpreted as: can we make sure that the first command after `set_option linter.minImports true` is *never* flagged and considered like a "reference" command.  This could be done: for instance the `minImportsRef` could be an `Option NameSet`, starting with `none` and, when it changes from `none` to `some ...`, the linter says nothing, but a change from `some ...` to `some (something else)` makes the linter speak.
These should all be `"`, not backticks.
Stray inscrutable comment here?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: the `minImports` linter
